messageBody:
"mamago@..." wrote:

> Bringing a newbie into OO
> ========================
> I would like to ask the people on this list for recommendations of the
> best literature to bring an OO newbie up to speed.

I'm looking forward to seeing the responses you get. This is an area
that has intrigued me ever since being defeated by SmallTalk, and
eventually entering the fold with Java.

I captured the essence of what I gleaned from interviewing several
helpful
O-O folks (Allen Holub and Steve Abell, in particular) in The JBuilder2
Bible (now out of print). Chapters 2, 12, and 13, in particular were
focused on summarizing O-O thinking, if you can find a copy.

The most eloquent, insightful people I know on the subject (in no
particular order) are:
* Martin Fowler
* Allen Hollub
* Peter Coad

Anything you can find by them is well worth a look.

Having read the previous post, I've ordered all three of the
books in the Coad & Yourdon series:
* Object Oriented Analysis
* Object Oriented Design
* Object Oriented Programming

The ratings on Amazon indicate that they would be quite good
for beginners.

Once a basic understanding of O-O concepts is acquired, The
Pragmatic Programmer is a good treetop view of the territory.
It's a great guide that points you to things you might want to
investigate further, so you know they're there, but without bogging
down in a lot of detail. (Which leaves you begging for more, in most
cases.)

Also:
* Fowler's "Refactoring" book is nothing short of brilliant.
* The Test-Driven Development book looks great, as well,
(but I haven't gotten to it yet)

I'm a big fan of "Document Driven Development", but I haven't
seen anything on the topic, so far. (Anyone know of anything?)

I've taken to starting projects with a User Guide, a bullet list
of Requirements, a collection of Design Notes, and a development
check list.

I cycle through the user guide and requirements documents, getting
feedback from users, and recording the results of experimentation
and investigation in the Design Notes document (which starts as a
series of notes on technologies the app will use).

As the design starts to emerge, I begin developing the implementation
checklist, which keeps getting revised for as long as the implementation

goes on. (For example, refactoring steps go into the checklist first,
and they get checked off as the refactoring goes on.)

When new information and design changes occur, they impact the
documentation first, and the code second. (When I get TDD down,
I suspect they'll affect the tests second -- or maybe even first.)

Of course, all of that depends on understanding objects and classes
and how to work with them effectively. Hopefully you'll find some
links to online papers among the replies to your query.

In the meantime, I'll query my publisher and see if we can find away
to put those 3 chapters online...
